I'm 48 minutes (my local time) late for my thing-a-day! Finally, here it is.
It's a flat (boring?) oval (can be perfectly circular too) open (of course, you can close it) asimetrical (thinner at the open side) bracelet (or ring if you make it smaller).
This design is intended to be an envelope to be boolean used (intersection) with other textured designs, we'll see...

This one is 60mm x 50mm (inside dimensions) and a little bit more than 29mm tall.
Thickness varies because is asimetrical. It should be a maximum of 3.6mm and a minimum of 2.1mm.
The opening has been set to 20mm, you can change all this, and more, in the OpenSCAD script parameters.
Use it to carve logos, textures, just write something on it or you can also print it as it is.
I've been mercy less with booleans and I go quite crazy with the resolution... it may take time to compile (decreasing the resolution by increasing "res" parameter speeds up the whole thing)

description.text:
This is a deflector for use in a 3D printing ventilation system, preventing water or gusts to blow directly into the exhaust overcoming a fan. It is low profile allowing for mounting in a screened in window.

Vanes start perpendicular to airflow, and turn to a 45 deg for supportless printing, and line of sight blockage. Airflow is relatively unaffected, except it is deflected down. For the lowest vane a cut out exists on the very bottom, printed fine in ABS without support.

There is loss in the duct, so maybe a fan controller would help a directly mounted fan to the hood, but there is still the turbulence from the flow not being straightened.  Maybe putting the fan up just 6in from the intake would be best, as I wouldn't have to worry about a special seal to the outside.

Hollow and windowed TARDIS you could stick a light in if you like.

My son was looking for a way to manage cables on the back of his desk from his computer, so I made this. It's easy to install, just place the hook so that the thin part is under the desk and the side with the hole is against the back of the desk. Use a small screw and screw it in. It should hold a bunch of cables pretty easily and shouldn't wobble around too much. I printed 5 of them and spread them evenly around the back of his desk for the cables.

Note, you'll have to move your desk from the wall a little since these sit behind the desk.

For best results, print sideways - no overhang issues that way.

title: Vertex K8400 GT2 belt upgrade tensioner

description.text:
After 6 months of good prints with the Vertex K8400 printer, I had problems with the quality of the prints. I tried readjusting, changing belts and I also upgraded to GT2 belts. At last I found that the problems were due to a worn out stepper motor. So an upgrade to GT2 belts was not really necessary. But now it is done, so I publish the GT2 belt fastener/adjuster that I created. You need to print 4 of this part and 4 mirrored parts.
I had to do some modifications to the printer to be able to use the new GT2 pulleys The pulleys I use has 20 teeth. I had to remove one of corner pieces on the right hand side to be able to adjust the tension for the servo motor. I also had to cut away most of the bearing holder on the left hand rear side because it interefered with the new pulley and belt. Now everything works fine and I'm happy with the print results. The last picture shows the difference between my old prints and the new. You can probably guess that the one to the right is the old print and the one to the left is the new.

Lock the pulley screws with Locktite 243. It keeps them tight, but they can still be unscrewed if needed.

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm

Infill:

10%

Changes to the printer configuration

Since the diameter of GT2 pulleys are different than the original T2.5 pulleys, the firmware has to be changed. So you need to modify the Marlin code. Find the Configuration.h file and change the line
# define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {134.74,134.74,4266.66,200}
to
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {160.88,160.88,4266.66,200}

The values may need to be changed after you made a testprint.
My measurement of a first test print of a 20mm box was 20.2 mm, so the value of 160.88 probably should be decreased by 1%, to 159.27.

Use the instructions here to upgrade the firmware: http://manuals.velleman.eu/article.php?id=31

description.text:
New Version for object cooling on Geeetech Prusa I3X Pro Acrylic version (I3B).
Mount a 40mm fan on it (I used common wood screws 3mm x 16mm).
Use some of the quadratic nuts and inbus screws (3mm x 20mm) which are left from your Printer assembly to mount the fan duct on the Extruder holder.
Geeetech always delivers more screws than needed.

Questions or suggestions? leave a comment!

Show me your makes.
happy printing!

comments.author: THSTS

comments.text:
I think your bottom plate of the extruder carriage is mounted upside down.
Simplify3D is the best slicing software in my opinion.
nevertheless it's not free of errors.
If something like this happens, I try to increase or reduce the layer height in Simplify3D and slice again.
Normally you should find a setting where slincing is ok.
comments.author: THSTS

comments.text:
Hi. This design looks great. I have a question.
The fan duct help to cooling the material freshly extruded? The airflow touch the hotend?
comments.author: isahi11

comments.text:
While printing the extruder crosses the object and the air cooles it.
The Fan duct directs the air to the object, not to the nozzle.
But of course it's possible that the air from the fan duct is reflected from the print object back to the nozzle...
comments.author: isahi11

author: cacvalle

description.text:
A simple and plain raspberry with a hole for attaching it as keychain. The outlines are painted with a permanent marker, but may be printed with a dual extruder setup, too. There are two different versions:
  • Raspberry-Solid: a solid raspberry with raised outlines
  • Raspberry-Borders-Only: a perforated version without eye
    • The raspberry was created with Inkscape as a SVG-file. I exported the two layers as separate DXF-files, which are used in OpenScad for linear extrusion. Maybe you prefer working with the sources...

Raspberry-Solid:
  • Slice model and print raspberries in desired quantity.
  • Optional: Use a permanent marker to highlight the borders.
  • Use attached hole for mounting it to a keyring, etc.
  • Enjoy your raspberry keychain ;-)
    • Raspberry-Borders-Only:
  • Slice model and print raspberries in desired quantity.
  • Use a thread or glue for mounting your raspberries.

comments.text: When I printed it seemed to be very thin. I scaled the Z by 1.5 and it seemed to do the trick. Also the key chain loop seems to be very thin and weak. I was able to snap it off very easily. However, scaling the Z by 1.5 fixed those problems

description.text:
MULTICALIBER FLAG CHAMBER

/------ French version BELOW ------\

Print it with high tempatures filaments ABS, NYLON, ... To avoid malting in chamber after lots of fire ...

  • One versatile, realy multicaliber, succesfully tested on Glock 17, M&P9 ( 9mm ), Sig Sauer P220 X-ZONE ( .45ACP ) , Coonan and S&W mod 27 ( .357Mag ) , DES 69, Berreta 89, CZ452 and GSG5 ( .22LR ), AR15 ( .223 REM ), VZ58 ( 7,62x39 ) Enjoy to test it on various other calibers and guns ...

  • And others, specifitly design for .22LR, 9x19, .357, .45 , .223(5.56 NAT0) , 7,62x39 calibers.

NON COMMERCIAL USE ONLY

You can add wonderfull flammes ont it like you can see ont the pictures

REMORE BEFORE FIRE flag/flammes
TONS of other flammes/flags

BEFORE LEAVING : PLEASE VISIT THIS LINK : European Union what take our guns AWAY

/------ Cocorico version ------\

Drapeau de chambre Multicalibre

A imprimer avec du filament qui tien les hautes températures genre ABS, NYLON, ... Sinon ça risque de fondre dans la chambre après avoir défouraillé ...

*Drapeau de chambre multi-calibre , fonctionne du .22 au 7,62x39 testé sur Glock 17, M&P9 ( 9mm ), Sig Sauer P220 X-ZONE ( .45ACP ) , Coonan and S&W mod 27 ( .357Mag ) , DES 69, Berreta 89, CZ452 and GSG5 ( .22LR ), AR15 ( .223 REM ), VZ58 ( 7,62x39 ) ... un normal et un plus épais pour les armes sans arrêtoir de culasse ...

*Drapeaux pour calibre spécifiques, .22LR, 9x19, .357Mag, .45ACP, .223REM , 7,62x39.

USAGE NON COMMERCIAL

Sur la petite boucle vous pouvez mettre de jolies flammes/flags à commander en A PAS CHER avec les liens suivants :

REMORE BEFORE FIRE flag/flammes
TONS of other flammes/flags

Avant de partir, pensez à signer la pétition contre le projet de l'EU de nous piquer nos armes

author: Bobot

print_settings.Notes:: There are 3 pieces that shoud be printed in high resolution 0.125 or less (see files) and 50% infill. The rest can be printed in lower resolution (0.25) and 25% infill.

title: Microphone Shockmount for Camera Shoe / Tripod / Stand

description.text:
Microphone shock mount for standard camera shoe. Use o-rings or rubber bands that best suit your setup. There are three lengths sizes of the piece "hinge" to choose the separation between the two "ring" pieces, reference pictures show the shortest one. There are also three sizes of the "joint" piece (that should be printed in high resolution), reference pictures show the shortest one.

1x M4 nut
2x M4 washers
1x M4x20mm screw (hex head)

1x M3 nut
1x M3x20mm screw (flat or pan head)

Edit: added an experimental rubberless ring for 21mm diameter mics. May neet to put some thin fabric between mic and plastic to avoid little displacement noises.

Edit: added piece "joint_stand", to screw the mount to standard 3/8" 16 microphone Stand and tripod head mount screws.

Licensed under The TAPR Open Hardware License

If you are a curious maker / "tinker" / hacker, have a look at my blog:
http://www.therandomlab.com

Printer:

Prusa i3

Resolution:

0.125 / 0.250

Infill:

25% / 50%

Notes:

There are 3 pieces that shoud be printed in high resolution 0.125 or less (see files) and 50% infill. The rest can be printed in lower resolution (0.25) and 25% infill.

Designed with Google Sketchup free 2016.

Screw and Nut threads adapted from YSoft_be3D's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:387266

description.text: Finding height with sight. With the use of trigonometry and a Hypsometer approximating height is a snap.

Printer:

QIDI Tech

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2-.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printing a raft significantly increases post cleaning on body section of Hypsometer.

Design

The idea and design was inspired by Dr. Brian James and a college Trig 2 class.
Overview & Background: You will gain skills related to trigonometry and its functions.

Lessons/Activity: 1-Lessons on basic trigonometry functions
2-Print, clean, and assemble Hypsometer
3-Tripod
4-Tape measure
5-Worksheet.

Project Name:

Hypsometer: Approximating height with sight.

Overview & Background:

You will gain skills related to trigonometry and its functions.

Objectives:

Students would be expected to learn how to approximate heights and slopes using basic trigonometry equations.

Audiences:

Students in High School grades 10th-12th and college math courses.

Subjects:

Math ,physics, science, and engineering courses.

Skills Learned:

Pythagorean theorem, Trig functions, and slope.

Lessons/Activity:

1-Lessons on basic trigonometry functions
2-Print, clean, and assemble Hypsometer
3-Tripod
4-Tape measure
5-Worksheet.

Duration:

Project should be able to be completed in one week or less.

Preparation:

Students need to have had a course on trigonometry and need to know how to read a tape measure.

References:

Dr.Brian James, Mrs. Debra Fisher, and Dr. Ed Owens of Pennsylvania College of Technology

Rubric & Assessment:

1-Printing and assembling the Hypsometer
2-Complete worksheet designed by instructor with objects of known elevations. Be creative.

Example:

comments.text: FWIW. I used something like this about 50 years ago when I was in 7th or 8th grade to measure the altitude attained by a model rocket.  Those ones had a plastic tube partially filled with water with food color, and you'd push down on a clamp to "hold" the liquid while you took the reading.

comments.author: tutankhamen

title: Rotary Dial (fake) for a flip phone

description.text:
This is a fake rotary dial for a flip phone.

My family and friends tease me about still living in the dinosaur age and having a flip phone. They may have their fancy phones with all those apps 'n things, but they don't have a rotary dial.

Hopefully this will bring a smile to somebody's face. Enjoy

You can glue the finger stop (small pointy thing) to the bracket before installing the dial.

Install the dial onto the bracket pivot before gluing the dome shaped cover to the top of the pivot post.

Be careful not to get glue on the sides of the pivot when you glue on the dome shaped dial cover or the dial will not turn.

The assembly is attached to the flip phone with a 3" rubber band.

first slide one end of the rubber band between the finger stop and top of the dial. Then underneath the dial to the slots in the bracket for the rubber band.

The other end of the rubber band is stretched behind the phone and into the other rubber band slots.

Great imagination !!
Thanks for sharing.

author: j_l_mortensen

print_settings.Notes:: I used a 40% infill for the main body with no horizontal layers, this is optional of course!

description.text:
Is the straight line always the shortest way?

Back in 2013 I visited the "Museo Galileo" in Florence, Italy. I was amazed on what I saw there and specially one object caught my attention. This wooden object made me think about the question asked at the begining of this lines...
When I saw this new version of the Maker Ed Challenge my mind went back to that object called The Brachistochrone.
Students can work different aspects of this item starting with a bit of History, following with some Technical Drawing and Maths and finishing with some Physics. I hope you enjoy creating your own Brachistochrone, here you will find all you need to do it. Good trip!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

BCN3D+

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 is ok

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a 40% infill for the main body with no horizontal layers, this is optional of course!
After printing all the parts you need to glue them together. Maybe your students will find better solutions for the final assembly?

Drawing the Cycloid

The key point of the Brachistochrone is the cycloid that forms the curved surface where the ball (in our case a marble) will slide.

In order to draw the cycloid the fist thing we must decide is its size. In the following example we are drawing a cycloid starting with a 50 mm radius circle.

First of all we must draw the starting circle and an horizontal line with the lenght of the circle's perimeter as show in the image below.

The starting circle and its perimeter

Then we must divide the circle in equal parts (in this example 12 parts). As many divisions you use the better the definition of the cycloid will be.

The horizontal line must be as well divided in the same amount of parts used for the circle. We will also draw a new horizontal line through the center of the circle.

Now vertical lines must be drawn starting in those divisions.

After that we will draw circles with the same radius than the starting one in every intersection between the upper horizontal line and the vertical ones. We will also draw horizonal lines through the end of the lines we used to divide the circle at the begining.

The final and most important step is to draw a line (in my case a spline) joining the points where de circles intersect the horizonal lines as shown in the picture below. This step is not easy to explain with words, please pay attention to the picture!

We have our cycloid ready for the next step. Great job!

Doubts?
There is a step by step explanation on how to draw a cycloid in this link:
http://edpstuff.blogspot.com.es/2010/07/cycloids-and-their-construction.html

Completing the design

Once we have the cycloid drawing now we can finish the design in different ways. I show the solution I choose for mine.

The holes are important to let the Brachistochrone work with different slopes. Designing the straight way

Now we need a straight path that will run paralel to our cycloid. Using both, cycloid and straight paths, we will compare the time it takes for the marbles to reach the crossing point between the two tracks and so we will see which one is faster.

The design of the straight track is quite simple. It can be done for example as shown below.

As you can see it has a semi circular path where the marble will slide. I also included a hole for a M4 bolt that will let the part rotate in order to get diferent experiments (with different inclinations).

Designing the feet

To hold the whole object some feet will be needed. They can be designed in many different ways, the important thing is that they fit well and give stability to the assembly.
My solution in shown below.

Final details

To finish the design process we will need a pin that will allow the straight track take different positions for diferent inclinations.

Another interesting part will let us release both marbles at the same time in the cycloid and in the straight tracks.

Assembly and other considerations

In order to get a Brachistochrone big enough to experiment the phenomenom I decided to split the main parts in two so we will need to glue them together once printed. As I wanted to give my Brachistochrone an special look, I printed the main body with no horizontal layers, this of course is optional an can be adapted to your own liking.

Project Name

This project is called Brachistochrone Curve as this is the name this kind of contraption takes from the ancient Brachistochrone Problem that tries to find the shortest time between two points. The word Brachistochrone cames from Ancient Greek βράχιστος χρόνος (brakhistos khrónos), meaning "shortest time".

The solution to the Brachistochrone Problem is the cycloid.

Brachistochrone Problem Overview & Background

This project can be taken form different points of view. It can be done from the Maths, Physics, Technical Drawing or History point of view. So the subject involved in this project can be one, some or all of them depending on the context and the kind of students we are teaching to.
Students can learn the theoretical part related to this problem with all its Maths concepts, the Physics behind the solution of this problem, how to design and draw the Cycloid and the Brachistochrone and the Historical part from Galileo to Johann Bernoulli solutions to this problem.

Objectives

Students will learn:

  • Brachistochrone Problem, meaning and solution
  • Drawing a cycloid curve
  • Designing an object composed of several pieces
  • Why the cycloid is the shortest way form point A to B
  • Who Galileo and Bernouilli where and how they contributed to our present knowledge
  • 3D printing techniques (of course!!)
Audiences

This project can be adapted depending on the age and skills os students but it would be optimum for students from 16 to 18 years old as they will understand better the whole process.

Subjects
  • Maths
  • Physics
  • Technical Drawing
  • History
  • Design
Skills Learned

Students will learn all (or at least some) of this skills:

  • Critical thinking, problem solving, reasoning, analysis, interpretation, synthesizing information
  • Research skills and practices, interrogative questioning
  • Creativity, artistry, curiosity, imagination, innovation, personal expression
  • Scientific literacy and reasoning, the scientific method
Lesson/Activity

To complet this project student will need some computers with internet conexion in order to design and develop the project.

A design software will also be needed, any software will work as the design itself is not complicated.

There is an step by step explanation on how to design and build the project prototype.

A 3D printer will also be needed.

The project can be started by posing the Brachistochrone problem to students and letting them some time to search for information and to think different solutions and designs for the prototipe they will finally build.

Then the design process will start and student will work in teams (for example) so each team will finally get their own design ready for 3D printing.

After 3D printing it will be time for experiments and to really see if theory becomes reality...

A piece of advice: use slow motion videos to compare both marble positions as it all happen so fast!;)

Examples:
https://youtu.be/_1DhpiR-xL4
https://youtu.be/NEINB9l4TYU

Duration

This project can be completed in 12 lesson hours (more or less)

Preparation

Students should already have some basic knowledge of 3D designing and 3D printing. A good background in Maths will also help.

References

Some references students and teacher may find useful:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachistochrone_curve

http://edpstuff.blogspot.com.es/2010/07/cycloids-and-their-construction.html

http://catalogue.museogalileo.it/object/BrachistocronousFall.html

https://www.google.es/search?q=Brachistochrone+Problem&client=firefox-b&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjCsLjH1JTOAhVMJMAKHe5rAbAQ_AUICSgC&biw=1920&bih=970#imgrc=_

The Brachistochrone you can find in Museo Galileo Rubric & Assessment

Students should have designed a complete 3D printed Brachistochrone prototipe according to the standards the teacher gave them.

They should also make a report explaining their experiments and the results they got from them.

Accuracy, originality and design quality will be taken into account.

author: chev383

title: Arrow II Ham Radio Satelite Antenna Mounts

description.text:
Created a few custom pieces to mount my Arrow II Satellite antenna on a tripod.

You will need:

  1. HT mount x 1 piece (minimal HT mount).
  2. Antenna mounts x 3 pieces (enhanced arrow II mount).
  3. Hillman Part #11139 ( Steel Flat piece - 1-3/8" x 3FT) - I purchased mine at Lowe's.
  4. A few machine screws, nuts, and washers - M5x19mm or similar.
  5. 1/4" threaded tripod screw to attach the antenna to a tripod.

I designed everything using Tinkercad. In addition, these are some of the first ever 3D printed parts I have designed from scratch. So, they may not be perfect - but should do the job.

If you can improve upon my design, please do so. Enjoy!

Antenna Mount Assembly

Locking the antenna into the 3 mounts is a little tricky. One must insert a nut sitting on top of a washer (to prevent it from falling through the hole on the steel flat piece) on the top and then insert a screw from the bottom which feeds through the steel flat piece, while being held in place by the antenna mount.

description.text: After fitting an E3D V6 to my printer, I noticed that the fan on the E3D V6 "slung" a lot of air down onto the part being printed. I also managed to slice my finger open on the running fan, so I decided to kill two birds... This duct allows the air to enter straight into the fan and not get thrown off to the side. It also keeps fingers out.

title: ZoneStar D810 Delta Spool holder support

description.text:
This is a modified spool holder support for a ZoneStar D810 delta printer. It replaces the original support to change the angle of the spool from 30 degrees to 60 degrees, to reduce the friction between spool and holder.

Many thanks to the ZoneStar people who shared their design file with me which made it much easier to create this.

[16 Aug]: Turns out this is not so good. The steeper angle means that the spool is no longer well-aligned with the extruder, so the filament is pulled across the spool and jams :(

[27 Aug]: V2 added. This moves the spool closer to the extruder.

Use M3 x 20mm screws to attach.

title: E3D Titan Extruder Bracket - Wilson II

description.text:
This is my Titan Extruder Bracket with Cable management bracket.

UPDATE: I have made the access to the Adjuster Screw to accommodate the new Thumb Screw Adjuster. All other dimensions are identical to my original.

There are some pros and cons with my design but the more I use it the more I prefer the orientation.

I have the adjuster screw at the back and on this setup with the Wilson II rack and pinion Z end stop it is a little hard to access. I cut down a alan key and although it's a little fiddly it get the job done. The pros are worth it... being able to use the large gear to wind in and out the filament is alone gold. Being able to clean the drive gear is easier than other designs and general access is good.

Note: This specific to the Wilson II X carriage with the Rack and Pinion Z end stop combined with a genuine E3D V6. If you are using a generic hotend it will most likely work and at the worst you will lose a little Z height.

If someone wants to use this on a non Wilson II Printer it will work fine but if you can give me some dimensions I can offset the bracket up which will give you some Z Axis height back but also give you clear access to the adjuster screw.

Hole pitch for the X carriage is 23mm x 23mm

Oh and I painted my Titan adjuster nut Red so I can see it.

You will need:

4x M4 Nuts
4x M4 Bolts

1x 2.5mm alan key cut to 10mm

There is a spacer for those without any cable management.

Here is the rest of my Cable Management system http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1670768

RepRap

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 X

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

0.2

50%

"Inspired by" the Hakko FA-400, this is a solder fume extractor designed to be used either horizontally for greater suction speed or verically for greater suction volume.  In the .stl files attached, it is configured to use a 120mm fan and the 130mm by 130mm carbon filter that goes with the actual Hakko extractor and its various knockoffs.  The filters for the Weller benchtop fume extractor should also fit.  The .scad file is parametric, so changing to a different sized fan or filter should just be a matter of changing a few numbers.

• Adjust the .scad file to fit a different sized fan or filter if you don't want to use a 120mm fan with a 130mm filter.
  • Print out the fume_extractor.stl
  • Optional: Print out the filter_holder.stl if the filter is loose. I found that it fit in snugly without the holder, but if the filter is falling out, you can use one.
  • Optional: Print out a fan grill for the other side of the fan. Here is the one I made for my 120mm fan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17028
  • Screw the fan into the extractor with fan screws if you have them of 1/2" #6 bolts if you don't.
  • Insert the filter, and optionally slide the holder in over it.
  • Power the fan. I used a 12v wall wart that I had left over from something else.

title: MKS TFT28 Detachable Tilt Swivel Enclosure

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the Color Touch Screen (MKS TFT28) controller.

Video demo available at: https://youtu.be/Q1aLKddd5WY

Detach
The console uses small (3mm) magnets to hold the console to the swivel-base. This allows the console to be picked up and operated like a smartphone (using thumbs).

Swivel
The swivel uses two 8x20mm bearings to connect to a 3/8inch threaded rod or bolt. The swivel can be snugged down using the horizontal knob (which can be turned "mostly" independent from the swivel).

Tilt
The stand can be tilted down slightly and quite a bit up, and over. A vertical axis knob can snug it into place.

Mounting:
A base that slides into aluminum extrusions comes with the package. The base can accept a 3/8 inch standard bolt head.

Updates:
2016-08-08 6:28 AM The previous version did not include the "Screen Holder". This part has since been added.

Printer:

Wombot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

25% to 80%

Notes:

All prints used PETG. Most were done using 3DXtech's carbon fiber PETG filament.

Clean up using steel-wool and a layer of clear coat

Personally, I like the Z lines of 3D printing, it strikes me similarly to the witness marks left behind by CNC machine; in means the part of created, not stamped or molded. So I "finish" the parts by knocking down any stray bumps or warts with steel-wool.

The carbon's "speckle" and print's layers can be brought out nicely with a simple layer of clear coat spray.
Fusion 360

description.text: Spot on Reader is a learning tool that is designed to help beginner readers sound out and pronounce new words. The design allows for easy adjustments of font size and sentence length to easily focus on specific letters, words, or phrases. It can also be used by those with learning disabilities and visual processing disorders. The slider easily moves to help people sound out words. The Spot on Reader’s sturdy and lightweight construction provides ease of use that is fast and easy to print.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print the main piece with support across the open bar where the slider fits. I would not recommend printing in white because there wouldn’t be the contrast desired against the white paper. It takes about 4 hours and 30 minutes to print on my printer and uses 14 grams of filament for all pieces.

I already created two other projects for the MakerEdChallenge2, so my ideas for what else to create were slowing down. I asked my mom, who is a speech therapist, what could really help the kids that she worked with or just kids in general. She said that a common problem is when she teaches students how to sound out words and to isolate syllables she has to use big pieces of paper that are hard to manipulate and get in the way. I came up with one prototype, but it was too flimsy and was not stable enough. I then thought of creating a main piece with two sliders that would adjust the font size and line distance. I created it with only sketches and extrusions. For design, I added in a picture and traced it in the sketch mode. I then extruded it inward to cut out the design. I also used the fillet feature to create some rounded edges. I had to make some minor adjustments to the slider to ensure a great fit. If you are trying to design something, I would recommend getting a digital caliper because it will help with getting very exact measurements.

Learning to read can be difficult for some.  The Spot on Reader can be utilized to isolate letters, syllables, words and sentences.  The design is made so the reader can use different books with varying font sizes.  The design was also allows the reader to isolate varying lengths of text.  This tool is used as a bridge to read more fluently.

Begin teaching the student how to read by sounding out single sounds, syllables, and words in easy to read books.  Then, advance to more difficult words, more complex sentence structure, and challenging books.
3D printer filament and something to read.

• reading
  • sounding out words

Project Name:

Spot on Reader

Overview and Background

Learning to read can be difficult for some. The Spot on Reader can be utilized to isolate letters, syllables, words and sentences. The design is made so the reader can use different books with varying font sizes. The design was also allows the reader to isolate varying lengths of text. This tool is used as a bridge to read more fluently.

Objectives

After using this tool, the student is expected to learn how to sound out words more fluently. They are expected to read faster and more fluently without the help of the Spot on Reader.

Audiences

The target audience for this product are students who are learning to read and sound out words.

Subjects

This product is versatile and can be utilized within any subject where reading text is necessary.

Skills Learned (Standards)

Spot on Reader assists students in learning how to read by isolating sounds, syllables, words, and sentences.

Lesson/Activity

Begin teaching the student how to read by sounding out single sounds, syllables, and words in easy to read books. Then, advance to more difficult words, more complex sentence structure, and challenging books.

Duration

Spot on Reader is generally utilized during the early stages of reading. The length of time to improve each student’s reading fluency is dependent on each student’s learning abilities.

Preparation

To prepare, first assess the student’s current reading ability and select a word, sentence, passage, or book that is only slightly challenging. Next, have them use Spot on Reader to help with the more difficult words by moving the slider as they sound out each syllable. If they do not read yet, read to them, having the student read the simpler words. You can also help the student by prompting them to finish words or sentences you have started.

References

None

Rubric and Assessment

Once the student has learned to read and pronounce new words without the help of Spot on Reader, they have completed what this product was trying to teach.

Handouts and Assets

I would recommend reading Dr. Suess books because the rhymes create repetition which helps with early reading fluency.

title: ServoBot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I set out to create this robot kit to give teachers, students, and hobbyists an affordable way to start learning and sharing robotics in their community. Most robotics kits that have the same functions as the ServoBot cost upwards of $150. Most schools, clubs, and maker spaces can afford a few, but not one for every 1 to 2 students. When I took on this project, I wanted to create a kit that people could put together themselves for under $40.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Resolution:

.4mm

Infill:

See note below.

Notes:

Printer settings and models were made for PLA.

For frame (X1), wheels (X2), sleeve(X2), and cap(X2), printer profile properties were set to:

Infill 30%

Print Speed 45mm/s

Print nozzle Temp: 200C

Bed Temp: 70C

Filament Diameter 1.75mm

Filament Flow 100%

Frame STL only.

Support type: Everywhere

Overhang angle 60 degrees

Fill amount 15%

Distance X/ Y 0.8mm

Distance Z 0.18mm)

All other STL files do not need supports.

NOTE: The Cap and Sleeve are for the IR LED. Use BLACK filament for these because it blocks infrared. I noticed other colors, like green, do not and splash the IR receivers with infrared.

For pins (X8), printer profile properties were set to:

Infill 100%.

All other properties settings remain the same

I designed the 3D models in this project using an open source application called FreeCAD and a metric ruler. I learned how to use FreeCAD by following a few tutorials for beginners I found on the introduction screen when you start the program. When I started the robot frame, I wanted the end product to to be sturdy, have very few parts, and have few to no bolts or screws. This is why I designed 3d printed pins to hold the servos in place. Once the frame was done, I designed the wheels so the top of the ServoBot would be level and to accommodate most 4 point horns that come with standard size continuous rotation servos. After more than 20 design modifications, I created a one piece frame that would hold two servos, ball bearing, battery harness, and circuit board with holes for cable management. I also designed a sleeve and cap for the IR LED's to save even more money on parts. Overall, I am very happy with the design and have already tested the platform with students and it performed well. Students and parents are very pleased with the robots and I will continue to use them in class. There are two disadvantages I have found with this design. First, once the circuit protoboard is placed on the top of the frame, it cannot be removed. So, if the frame becomes damaged, you must replace the frame and protoboard. Second, the pins designed to hold the servos in place are one shot devices--if you have to take them out, they must be replaced. Make sure you print extra pins. Overall, I am very happy with the design and how it has performed.

Overview & Background:

The purpose of this project is to give fellow educators an affordable robot platform for students at their school, youth group, or club to build, program, and experiment. After teaching students about robotics, most students wanted to take the robot home. However, the cost was too prohibitive. Once my class bought a 3d printer, I saw this as an opportunity to create a programmable robot that 1 to 2 students could build, program, and then take home and continue to learn and experiment.

Objectives:

As students work to complete the ServoBot, they will learn to wire an electronic circuit board, install software and connect their circuit board to the computer for testing and troubleshooting, construct the robot platform using common hand tools, and finally, program the ServoBot to use sensors and servo motors to interact in different ways with its environment.

Audiences:

This project is recommend for kids (5th through 12th) and adults wanting to learn more about robotics.

Subjects:

Computer Science, Computer Programming, Technology Education, Electronics, Robotics, Pre-engineering, Science, Physics

Skills Learned (Standards):

After completing this project, students will be able to:

Know when to wear personal protective equipment (PPE) to protect both themselves and equipment.

Safely wire and handle electronic components.

Construct an electronic circuit onto a prototype board.

Download and Install Arduino IDE onto a computer.

Connect an Arduino Microcontroller to a computer.

Upload a sketch from a computer to an Arduino Microcontroller.

Execute a sketch on an Arduino Microcontroller.

Monitor the output of a sketch from an Arduino Microcontroller from a computer.

Use common hand tools to construct a robot chassis.

Calibrate continuous running servos.

Program the ServoBot using functions to make it maneuver forward, backwards, turn in place, and turn left or right.

Program infrared sensors on the ServoBot so it can detect objects and avoid them.

Write more efficient code so the ServoBot has better performance.

Change the ServoBots behavior from avoiding objects to following objects by changing its coding.

Lesson/ Activity:

Please refer to the ServoBot_Construction_and_Programming_Manual_8-13-16.pdf for more information on construction and programming activities.

I made this PDF file so that students could view it on a computer, tablet, or printed on paper and handed out with each kit. I wanted to make it convenient for a wide range of classes and educators to use.

If instruction and project time is limited, code can be copied and pasted into the Arduino IDE from the manual or activity code text files (located in the Thing Files Section).

Duration:

Can be completed in as little as 6 hours. For more in depth coverage of programming concepts:15 hours or more.

This project can be used in:

1 day science camps

1 week science camps

Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts to help earn Merit Badges or Patches

Youth groups and Pre-Teen groups.

Preparation:

Please refer to the ServoBot_Bill_of_Materials_BOM.pdf for more information on the parts needed to build the ServoBot. The BOM contains links to vendors to make finding and buying these items easier. All items can be found at other places, so you can use your favorite vendor. However, pay special attention to the size of the battery holder, servo horns included with the servos, and IR LED's diameter before ordering to make sure they will fit. Also, don't forget to buy your preferred brand and color of filament.

Equipment & Tools:

3D Printer

Computer (Preferably one for each ServoBot)

Small diagonal cutters

Small needle nose pliers

Wire strippers

Pen

Safety glasses.

Anti-static wrist strap.

Hack Saw

Jeweler’s screwdriver set w/ #1 Philips Screwdriver

Smooth cut metal file

References:

Arduino Website

Go here to download the Arduino IDE software.

(This website is great for beginners new to the arduino. Also, it has great code ideas if students want to experiment adding additional sensors to the ServoBot.)

Rubric & Assessment:

Assessment is determined by the instructor.

Examples for scoring include:

Participation.

Quality of robot construction.

Does robot perform as stated in the activities' descriptions?

Do students experiment with modifying the code to see how this affects robot performance?

Handouts & Assets:

Also included in the Thing Files Section is a:

ServoBot_Bill_of_Materials_BOM.pdf
ServoBot_Construction_and_Programming_Manual_8-13-16.pdf
Controller Board Schematic

print_settings.Printer:: FFC Pro and Rostock Max V2

description.text:
Latest UPDATE 8/14/16 Added a Straight Coupling Adapter for the clear hose listed, see pictures, works with all existing parts but now allows easy plug and unpluging of the hose and I use the Vent plug when ventilation system is not in use.

This is meant to be a full ventilation kit for a Flashforge Creator Pro.

You will need to print:
-Top Replacement pieces for FFC Pro: FFC PRO Vent Top Left and Right (2 pieces total)
-Duct to mount to top of new FFC Pro Top: 4in Vent adapter from ffcp01 file duct.mount (1)
-A 120mm Fan to 4in Vent Hose adapter (1)

Recommended to print but not needed:
-120mm exhaust cap (designed for smooth exhaust directed downward with blocked line of sight, preventing most drafts and rain)
-FFC PRO Hood Plug Remix (Trapping additional heat inside for printing ABS)
-Some form of side plugs, many available on thingiverse (to trap heat)
-4in Vent Plug (for when not in use in an air conditioned home, I originally intended for this to be wrapped in a compliant tape like electrical tape but this is not sealing as well as I'd want, and will likely make another version in the future)

You will need to buy:
-1x 120mm fan (you can use more, or use a different fan setup with a different adapter), I used a Corsair SP https://www.amazon.com/Corsair-SP120-High-Performance-Twin/dp/B007RESFYK
-1x 4in Duct hose, I originally purchased https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003CLL9V8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 and the fittings are currently setup to take both hoses as pictured, but I prefer this: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000DZFTEO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 which is more flexible.
-1x 12 volt power supply, anything will do to power one fan, I used: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000MGG6SC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (it really can only power two fans and there is a good speed drop)
-4x #8 or #6 screws, depending on how accurate your hole drilling is :) 2.5 to 3in long, and nuts

  • 4x #8 or #6 screws, depending on how accurate your printing is :) 1in long and nuts
    -1x piece of 1inx6inxwidth of your window, I used cedar which is recommended, or you will need a painted board or weather resistant material if you want it exposed

Nice to haves:
-Foam and tape to seal the window sash where open above, and stick on foam around the board, mine is sealed pretty tight.
-A way to make this work between my fan and the outside http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529661 I haven't tried yet but would be a nice solution, short of that there will be a sliding door eventually, for now the plug.

With everything above I am able to print abs without warping, and without any hint of fumes. Note the Exhaust port pictured, that was printed with this setup, without it installed.

I still recommend running a in room hepa filter for any leftover fumes, but at least I don't mind staying in the room while its printing.

There were some great files I remixed from, thanks to BrookTrout, ffcp01, and ADN_NMX for having your good ideas posted for sharing.

Let me know if you have better ideas, and suggestions. This is version 1, will likely be improved, and have an adapter for the rostock max.

UPDATE: 8/8/16 -> Received the clear hose today from amazon (pictured), much easier to work with (if a danger to easy puncture, avoid animals). The fit is a bit off on my current setup of adapters, I may have to remix the linked 4in outlet and the 120 to 4, but it works pretty well. I would recommend getting the clear hose if you don't have a danger of tearing the plastic (there is a pic of both to help you choose, both are $10).

UPDATE 8/14/16 Added a Straight Coupling Adapter for the clear hose listed, see pictures, works with all existing parts but now allows easy plug and unpluging of the hose and I use the Vent plug when ventilation system is not in use.

FFC Pro and Rostock Max V2

No

No

.15-.35

Infill:

7-15%

Notes:

These were printed on two different printers in PLA and ABS. Anything outside needs to be in ABS or something durable.

remixed_from.title: Rubik's cube for the blind (fully printable)

description.text:
This is based on chapulina's printable Rubik's cube. I recently saw this cube and it gave me an idea:
http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b162/nostalgia75/cubing/guhong_pieces.jpg Why not cut a cube piece in half in print it in color? so this is the result. If you have 6 colors of filament, you can print one print plate in each color, or you can use the filament colorizer and 5 colors of sharpies.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11742 This is a work in progress, i have yet to add a way to align the pieces (such as a pin connector).

First, if you do not have 6 colors of filament, print our cyclone's filament colorizer. Then print 6 print plates, each in a different color. Print a Core Print Plate as well. Now, glue each piece together, depending on your color choice/position. Assemble according to chapulina's build instructions:
http://myshumi.posterous.com/cube-for-the-blind-3d-printed

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the M42 thread prints directly and shouldn't need any post processing. A little detail with M42 is that many adapters don't have the thread stop the lens at the right rotational position... this one should -- at least it does with the lenses I've tested.

title: M42 Lens To Leica M Body (Techart Pro LM-EA7) Adapter

description.text:
M42 is the "universal" screw thread mount for SLRs that is usually associated with Praktica and Pentax. It was actually used by many brands, including Fujica, Mamiya/Sekor, and Zenit. Because it is an open standard and has a relatively long flange distance, it has also been a very popular mount for adapting to other mounts (notably excluding Nikon F). There are many commercial adapters for M42 lenses to other mounts, including Leica M.

Ok, so why 3D print this one? Because we can seems like a decent answer -- this is an easy print in 1 piece, including the M42 screw thread. However, there are two even better reasons. The first is that an M42 to M adapter allows the latest Sony E mount bodies to autofocus these manual lenses via the Techart Pro LM-EA7 adapter... which has a 700g weight drive limit, so we don't want to waste weight on a heavy adapter. The second is that later Mamiya/Sekor M42 lenses had the aperture ring extend back around the mount flange, but commercial adapters have overly wide flanges that prevent those lenses from mounting. Actually, there is also a third potential issue in that some M42 adapters are too thick on the M side to fit on the LM-EA7. In any case, this adapter avoids all these problems.

The last two shots were taken using the LM-EA7 autofocus with the manual Mamiya/Sekor 55mm f/1.8 lens shown. Note that you can shift the autofocus range closer by not leaving the manual focus ring set to infinity.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

A very straightforward print. I used "dishwasher safe" high-temp black PLA. It should be a little tight, so work a lens in the mount a bit before attaching to a camera -- that way, you can clean any little shards that the flange might cut the first time you fit a lens to it.

Note that the M42 thread prints directly and shouldn't need any post processing. A little detail with M42 is that many adapters don't have the thread stop the lens at the right rotational position... this one should -- at least it does with the lenses I've tested.

Usage Notes

Be a little careful starting threading a lens on because the metal thread on the lens can damage the printed thread if you cross thread it.

This adapter does NOT have a ledge to depress the stop-down pin found in the back of most M42 lenses. Thus, the lens must be set to operate in MANual, not AUTOmatic, aperture mode. See http://www.instructables.com/id/M42-Lens-Aperture-Control-on-Modern-DSLRs/ for details.

description.text:
This is socket peg hook, I have thought of this because a lot of my tools were given to me from my father. He would just throw his tools in his box and it was a clutter. Truth is, it still is. I can find more 1/2 in drive sockets then I can find the right tool for the job. this is for a peg board with a near 5 mm hole, and the pegs are for 1/4" 3/8" and 1/2" drive.

The story of the peg board, now that is a different story. One day I thought to myself it would be nice to have a heat gun. They're fairly cheep and its not a bad idea to have one. (unless you have no use for one, which I found out quickly I didn't.) I used it once to crisped bacon on a roast, and that was really good. Now comes the time of the practical use, I thought for a second and I need a vacuum forming box and the peg board would be a great choice. Long story short I have peg board to model my pegs.

title: EE Electrical Breadboard Cabinet Stackable Case - Parts - UPDATED Control Panel and Cabinet Wall Support

description.text:
I have seen an assortment of Breadboards, Blocks, Cases, etc.
I have not yet found something that I found useful enough to be comfortable with, besides the Foldable Breadboard / Arduino Cases - which I also designed & printed my own versions of.

This seemed to fulfill the needs that I commonly look for:

  • Mounted Breadboard
  • Control Panel for Mounting Parts
  • Spare Parts Case - the Drawers

This Control Panel is setup for mounting:

  • LEDs
  • Switches
  • Potentiometers

Assembly requires the: BreadboardTrayFloor , 2 Drawers , 2 StdCtr Parts , 2 StdSide Parts , 1 CntlPnl - and GlueGun suggested.
The 2 StdSide Parts are glued under the sides of the Tray - as side Legs.
The Drawers are individually temporarily slid in to adjust and glue in the StdCtr Parts, in the center bottom of the Tray - as Center Legs.
The CntlPnl is glued onto the rear of the Tray.
When dry, the Drawers can then be slid back in.

For the TENTACLE PROBES , see:

  • 1711909 - EE Electrical Tentacle Probes - for EE and Arduino Cabinet

Also these are Stackable.
To stack them, you can either mount the StackLegs on the Board sides individually, or buil a Cabinet to slide the Tray-Drawer Boards in.

To create a shelf, mount the multiple StackLegs vertically to desired height , then horizontally via a bottom shelf with the SupportFloorWall Part and in the rear with another SupportFloorWall Part.
Then slide the Boards into the Shelves.

Hope this is useful !

author: Brytard

description.text:
Coal Dog

Check out the video https://youtu.be/C4T1LmaF0wc

The hound that sniffs out and eliminates tough odors from your refrigerator.

  • The latest addition to the Butter Pig Barnyard Family of Friends

Coal Dog keeps your refrigerator smelling fresh and clean, all year round. Since ancient times, man has kept a box of baking soda in the fridge to eliminate odors. Recent scientific research suggests that regular ordinary charcoal can be even better at this task, and potentially lasts even longer.

  • Note: do not use the kind of charcoal with lighter fluid in it.
Printing Instructions

No rafts or supports needed! Print from anything you want. The pupils and tip of the nose are printed separately so you can make them different colors.

Assembly

There are three STLs to print: the face, the nose, and the tip of the nose/pupils. Everything press fits and snaps into place, no gluing or other nonsense required.

Just slide the nose onto the face and snap it in place. Slide the nose tip down from the top, and press fit in the pupils, locking the nose in place.

Use

Place 5 charcoal briquettes in a bag, and crush them gently with a hammer. Apply some double sided 3M tape to the back of the dog's head, and stick it to the inside wall of your refrigerator somewhere out of the way. Attach the nose, and fill it with the charcoal.

For even better results, you can activate your charcoal using calcium carbonate, or buy activated charcoal at any aquarium supply store.
This Dog is printed in Ecolink white PLA at 0.2mm layers One-Piece Coal Dog Prototype Printed in Blue PETG by https://www.3dhubs.com/indianapolis/hubs/blitzjon

print_settings.Notes:: see description for details.

description.text:
This is the process I use to calibrate each filament. Part of the process I read about a while ago and for the life of me cannot find the site to give credit, if I do I will add it.

I start by printing the 20x20x5mm cube with the following settings in Simplify3d.

Extruder tab

  • Extrusion Multiplier - 1.00
  • extrusion width - manual - 0.48mm (assuming 0.40mm nozzle)

Layer Tab

  • primary layer height - 0.20mm
  • top solid layers - o
  • bottom solid layers - 0
  • outline/perimeter shells - 2

Infill - 0

Print the output stl and measure the width of the of the shells. the goal is 0.96mm if its under 0.96mm go back to simplify3d and adjust extrusion multiplier till you get as close as possoble to 0.96mm.

Once the extrusion multiplier is set turn to the 3 hole test stl.

I made this stl to test holes for a few things I use often, the holes are 6.5mm, 3.2mm and 2.7mm. I use the 6.5mm for SMA fitment, 3.2mm for M3 screw pass though and 2.7mm to thread an M3 screw into.

On the Other tab in Simplify 3d use the Horizontal size compensation to get the holes to the correct size. positive numbers make the holes smaller, negative numbers make the holes larger.

Printer:

MP Select mini

Rafts:

No

description.text:
West Coast Remix

You asked for it! Finally, here it is:

A Butter Pig fit for those big, stocky blocks of butter they serve up West of the Rockies.

  • The Latest Addition to the Butter Pig Barnyard Family of Friends

This is a remix of Blitzjon's Baconlicious Butter Pig, which was a remix of my original Butter Pig with quite a few improvements to make it more easy to print.

Phoolster pointed me to this article on Wikipedia which I used to get the dimensions right. When I designed the original Butter Pig, I had not idea butter was sold in so many shapes and sizes around the world. Within the US alone, there are actually two different competing sizes of sticks of butter. Although they weigh the same amount, the sticks on the West coast are shorter and fatter than the longer, thinner sticks they sell in grocery stores east of the Rocky Mountains.

A Complete Tear Down and Overhaul

Every part had to be resized, including the dies. The feet were almost reusable, but because this pig sits with a wider stance, the feet are now four separate feet instead of two attached sets of two. The tail and the body are now shorter so this should be able to be printed on just about any printer.

Multiple Storage Options

There are two versions of the knoll, or pig pen. One is full size, and holds three dies, the other is smaller so that it will fit on my printer, and holds only two.

I have printed several of these (the one seen here is made from Food Grade PETG ) However, I have not been able to acquire a stick of Western-Pack butter for myself to try it out. Please try it for yourself and let me know how it fits.

As always, keep uploading pictures of your Butter Pigs!

I've also included a new die that I call the butter noodle.

Video https://youtu.be/MJ3z2VeMv4g

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Like the Baconlicious Mix, the West Coast Butter Pig can be printed with little to no supports or rafts. I did use a raft on some of the parts like the dies because their shape makes them more vulnerable to curling.

Smaller Knoll made in green PETG A closer look at the new Noodle die

Check out my original butter pig at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:552508

Also don't forget to visit the entire Butter Pig Baryard Family of Friends at http://www.thingiverse.com/steveweber314/collections/butter-pig-barnyard-family-of-friends

Butter Pig Always Makes a Great Gift

Pass it around the Thanksgiving table, so each of your guests can grab a slice of pure, sweet butter. No more fussing with a complicated dish, or losing track of the butter knife. Butter tastes great on rolls, toast, garlic bread, croissants, corn, mashed potatoes, pancakes, noodles, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, carrots, biscuits, bacon, and more!

*When using the extrusion attachments, leave the butter out of the icebox to soften for an hour first.

User Testimonials

It Was Butter Than Ever

"Slicing butter was accurate and easy with the new butter slicer. Slices of spreadable butter adorned the bread of grilled cheese sandwiches at last night’s dinner caper. Thanks, Steve!"
--Jennifer from Indianapolis

Should you feel inclined to tip the designer on this one, the proceeds will go toward building my new printer, which you can read about on my blog: http://steves3dprinterbuild.blogspot.com/

This will allow me to keep expanding the Butter Pig Family with new bigger better inventions. Thank you!

comments.text:
For some reason, no matter what I did would make the plugin work. I am using Cura 2.3.1. I placed the plugin folder into Cura's "Plugins" folder, but it would not recognize and load the plugin. So, I just printed one wheel at a time up at the front/left part of my bed (on my ANET A8) and I used Cura's "Pause at Height" script.
That is, after pulling in the STL into Cura, I clicked on "Extensions" - "Post Processing" - "Modify G-Code" - "Add a script" and then chose the "Pause at height" script. I input "4.2mm" for the height, and left the next two lines (which were called 'Park Print head X' and 'Park Print head Y' at their values of 190mm and 190mm.
Then, I just sat by the print and waited for the print height to get close to 4.2mm. As it approached 4.2mm, I had the M3 nut in my fingers. At 4.2mm, the print head traveled to the opposite end of the print bed, which gave me plenty of time to drop the nut in place before the print head returned. Note that my print speed settings were at 45mm/s print and 60mm/s travel. One could get more time by changing the travel speed to 30. I'm not sure how big a difference that would make, since Cura tells me that it makes no impact to the time it would take to print one wheel (11 minutes). Thanks for the great design! I hope my long comment helps someone!
comments.author: craigcole

comments.author: Tavero

comments.text:
@Ratm3at thanks for sharing this is great. I use Slic3r and Octoprint. I sliced it and exported the GCode to a file. Loaded the file in Notepad and scanned all the lines with a Z in it and then found this one: G1 Z4.300 F5400.000. (Hinting that we are at roughly 4.3mm high)
Just before that I added:
G1 Z80
M0 S120
M0 S120
Which moves the Z axis to 80mm.
With Octoprint, the M0 just pauses until you press the "Play" button again. So the First one I don't think requires the S120 (for 2 minutes) and I don't think the second one is required either. But it works.
I can then squish in a standard M3 nut and hit the Resume button and we are good to go.
Thanks again for sharing!

comments.text: It can't be printed without the pause. Something you could try if you can't get the plugin pause to work...... Try printing this with another "random" print on the back of the build platform. Then when the nozzle gets to the correct height and moves to the other object you can use the pause button on the machine or your USB connection menu. Drop in the nut then resume printing. Sorry that it's not working for you, I could redesign the part for a press fit nut.

title: OpenRC 1:10 RC Hybrid Central Differential Gear

description.text: This is a hybrid central differential gear inspired by the work Steamerzone has done for the "OpenRC almost all metal rugged driveline" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162810). Print the gear ring in nylon (e.g. Taulman 618) and the inner part in ABS. Both parts slide together and can be further secured with a drop of CA (in my case the press fit alone was enough). Alternatively you can print both materials at the same time with a dual extruder machine. This combines the strength and flexibility of nylon for the gears with the stiffness of ABS for the central housing.

title: Honda Insight Switch Mount and Blanking Plates
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I'm working on a project where one of my goals is to not to make any permanent alterations to my car, but I do need to mount a switch. Many cars have "blanking plates" the fill the holes where buttons would go for options that you didn't order or that aren't available in your market. Usually drilling holes in one of these plates is a harmless enough way to mount a switch, but in this case I wanted the switch to be mounted flush, and I have a 3D printer, so I popped them out of the dash and took some measurements to make my own.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

5%

Notes:

The original (2000-06) Honda Insight has a row of 3 blanking plates in the dashboard between the steering column and the door. As far as I can tell, the smaller ones on the sides are a size specific to the Insight and the one in the middle fits a switch also found in the original (1997-2001) CR-V.
Anyway! The files ending in 1 are for the smaller Insight-specific hole, while the files ending in 2 could possibly also fit an early CR-V.

This is the switch the switch mounts are designed to fit: https://www.radioshack.com/collections/maker-parts-kits/products/spst-12v-dc-illuminated-switch-3 You can find switches that are nearly identical but much cheaper elsewhere online by doing a search for "12V 30A switch". You can also alter the files to fit other switches.

I recommend printing the switch mounts at .1 or possibly even finer if you can, mostly for finish but also because 1 is barely bigger than the switch itself so the bezel is quite thin. I printed both with supports and a thin helper disc.

The replacement blanking plates can probably be printed face down and at a lower resolution.

Car interiors can get very hot parked in the summer, so keep that in mind when making your plastic choice. I printed mine in Inland black ABS.

comments.text: Very cool idea and it look good too.

title: Plastic Gear for 90 Degree Motion Transfer

description.text:
A light duty alternative to metal, use these plastic gears to transmit motion at a 90° angle while maintaining speed and torque. They’re also known as miter gears.

For two gears to mesh correctly, they must have the same pressure angle, pitch, and number of teeth. Use these gears with other gears that have a 20° pressure angle.

Extra Details

Set Screw
All files include a metric set screw hole, set to 2.6mm for a snug 3mm screw fit.

Students are given a riddle from Harry Potter. The solution was not given in the book. To solve this riddle, students will need to first create 7 bottles. They can then use the clues to figure out what order the bottles go in.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

I used the Makerbot PrintShop app. One of the options is to design your own vase. I designed 7 different size vases to look like bottles. I reduced the size to 25% to print. You may want slightly larger bottles. Please note that this app is only available for the iPad. Another option would be for students to design bottles using a different software.

Students will get practice problem solving and using logic. Objectives:
Students will develop their logic skills, which is an important part of mathematical proofs, including geometry proofs. Skills Learned (Standards):
CCSS.Math.Practice.MP1 Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.

Students can work in groups. On the worksheet they are given some background and the riddle that appeared in Harry Potter. Then they are asked to design and print 7 bottles, all of different sizes. I used the Makerbot PrintShop app because the design is very easy. If you don’t have access to iPods you can also use other software, it will just take longer to design the bottles. Each group member can design one or two bottles, depending on the size of the group. Those will take a while to print so you can resume this activity the following day. The next day students will try to set up their bottles so that there is only one possible solution to this riddle. Then they will label each bottle and trade with another group to solve theirs. In the solution worksheet I gave one possible answer.

This activity will probably need to be done over two days. The first day would be to introduce the riddle and to design the bottles. They would probably need to be printed overnight. This won’t take the full class. (Perhaps also do the fox, goose, and a bag of beans activity http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696602). The second day students can solve the riddle.
Students don’t need any background knowledge to do this activity.

This activity can be done without an assessment or can count for a participation grade. Question (points)
Participation in designing bottles (3)
Participation in setting up bottles (7)
Participation in solving the riddle (5) Total 15

title: Spool Roller for Hatchbox Tabletop Wall Mount Rack

description.text:
Spool Roller for Hatchbox Tabletop Wall Mount Rack

Yes, this is yet another spool roller specifically for the Hatchbox Tabletop Wall Mount Rack. These are attached to your filament spool prior to being used with the rack to give an easier rolling spool. I got tired of spools not rolling well on the rack and decided to make a bearing support so the spools would roll freely on the rack.

Bung is tapered to accept most spool sizes - check your spool diameters before making.
Smallest spool size is: 49 mm diameter
Largest spool size is: 59 mm diameter

For each set you will need six (6) 605ZZ bearings, and three (3) long screws (or similar) - I used three (3) inch long dry wall screws (see photos). Will also need six (6) M3 x 0.5 screws 15 mm long.

Sources:
605ZZ Bearings:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B008X18PNC

Hatchbox Spool Table top Rack:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00RC0M8Q0

Dry wall screws - 3" long
https://smile.amazon.com/Grip-Rite-3CDWS1-3-Inch-Coarse-Drywall/dp/B000BOALP4

M3 Screws:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B014ONCP88
Note: can also use 4-40 pan head screws

Printer:

Folger Tech i3 2020 Alum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20% Rectilinear

Notes:

Printed with PLA but ABS will work
Designed in FreeCAD - see attached file.

description.text:
Interlocking snap-together tubing that can hold its position reasonably well. I'm using it for re-positionable GoPro mounts.

It is compatible with commercial interlocking tube of similar diameter. In all honesty, it is not as air-tight as the real thing and doesn't have quite the holding power but for fairly simple tasks it works just fine. As I'm printing with a standard FDM printer it can be difficult to snap and adjust initially but as some of the layers wear down it loosens up.

I've printed a thousand of these however I'm still tweaking it every now and then.

Printer:

Folger Prusa i3

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print the standard interlocking tube upside-down (small hole on the bed) as the pressed layers can make it harder to snap. The GoPro mount should be printed with supports.

I prefer PETG for these as it has more give before breaking.

title: GE220 replacement 5mm spacer (FC screw holes removed)

description.text: This is a 98% clone of the GE220 5mm spacer. It's not completely identical to the original, but as close as I could get it. I removed the flight controller screw holes so the screws don't have to poke out the bottom of the frame and and have the battery sit on them. And so you can use shorter screws to mount the FC.

author: Miou31

description.text:
IMPORTANT! I have found a lot of issues with this design after printing. I will be uploading a V.2 soon.
This case is for a mini itx build.
Holes on front panel are for:
15mm momentary power button
5mm LED holder and LED
screw mount usb ports.

Holes on the back are for:
Mini itx power supply
50mm fan
I/O shield

You will also need a mobo tray. I am temporarily using this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24270 I will update this once I have made one for this case.

There should be room in the bottom for a couple 2.5" drives. I plan to make built in drive holders and will update after I have done so.

In the future I would like to add some cable routing channels, expand the case a bit to house a gpu and an all in one liquid cooler as well as post an unbranded model.

This fits on my i3 with a 200mm x 270mm print bed. Anything smaller than that and it will have to be cut up.
Added in some minimal supports using Meshmixer

description.text:
This is a remix: ""untested"" of :- 3D Printed Project - Acoustic Stand for Amazon Echo Dot!

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1687425

It idea is to add some holes to see it the sound levels are increased by the empty space in the center may be able to be used as a resonance chamber to boost sound even more, some holes for sound to travel in and back out;

This is ""untested"" I do not have an Amazon Echo Dot :)

BUT see:

Lattice Structure Absorbs Vibrations

http://www.scienceandtechnologyresearchnews.com/lattice-structure-absorbs-vibrations/

.

comments.text: I printed the version without the extra holes and the bass is certainly improved (1st gen Dot). I'd see these extra holes more acting to improve airflow, and I wonder if having them so large might actually reduce the even reflection/distribution of the sound?

title: GEEETech i3B/C (METAL version): Single Extruder FAN & LED (V2)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
now GEEETech proposes the Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series, B for single extruder and C for dual extruder, with metallic parts instead of original printer ones.
Quite immediately I’ve ordered the upgrade kit in order to improve the stability and the quality of my, already not-so-bad printer, unfortunately the customization I’ve designed for the plastic version of this printer cannot be used on the metal one, so I’ve started designing a completely new customization, starting with all lesson learned from my original customization!
One, main, lesson learned was to decouple all contact, in order to enable easy mounting, maintenance and upgrade!
Here the Mono Extruder FAN & LED component of my new customization in his second iteration version!
In this design you can find place to put ties in order keep in position all cables, as you can see in my photos!
I’ve added some option component:

1) For FAN Duct you can find closed & open version, I prefer closed one but I know that lot of people can love open version!
2) For ABL sensor you can find support for both rectangular IR sensor like my one and PiBot one
3) For Rectangular ABL sensor you can also fine the 4D design, in order to print flat!

As usual in all my design I’ve split all in order to have an easy print of each, and also an easy mounting after print!

From the V1 this V2 have also the duct to collect MK8 fun versus the cool zone, in order to better cool down the barrel, and that because with some filament that ask more degree in HE, this 38mm barrel seam have some problem to be correctly cool, and sometimes it clog…

PS: after the installation of this customization is a good Idea to re-execute the PID Autotest… I’ve do two time, one with fan power off and one with fan power on, and both was really different from the same test executed just couple hours before!

I'm not really sure how to even categorize this project. it crosses into many other projects I'm working on, but basically this is a set of cable covers designed to allow upper gantry wiring for LCD's, sensors, etc., and lower gantry main wiring to pass without wires being visible, and in most case into these extrusion slot covers: http://www.mcmaster.com/#47065t93/=13j4f4b

The lower pieces work best with the Taz 3 control box, though others would work too. The LCD back section works with All Taz variants, though the bottom portion would be Taz 3 specific. The Lightbar ends work with my other lightbar pieces. and a new full revision of the lightbar project is in the works.

I've been dumping these files and development stuff related to them in my "sensor Project" thread in the Lulzbot forum here:
https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=2134&start=20

These mainly bolt on. The ones that need support have it already in the model. You will need a few M3 heat set inserts for the lower cable path cover, but thats only really useful for Taz 3 users anyways.

More to come, I'll have more pictures and wireing progress when I get to that stage with this unit

These are designed to work with the Taz specifically, but should also fit many 20mm extrusion based printer designs.

description.text:
This is a metric version of the old "A-Justo-Jig" concept. Rib support rods are 5mm carbon fibre at 50mm centres and the main tube is 16mm aluminium with base tube of 25mm square aluminium.
The central dihedral bracket is 3mm aluminium angle, 280mm long. The 5mm bolt slots are 10mm from the ends giving up to 8 degrees dihedral angle per side. Only one angle bracket is needed at 3mm thick but add the second side if using a lighter gauge.
All bolts are 5mm diameter, 30 to 40mm long with wing nuts, plain and split washers.
Fuselage adaptors are also included with optional 25mm square tube adaptors allowing them to make a separate jig. The side bars can also be cascaded to add length or cater for compound shapes.
The Openscad files are included so you can adjust to suit local material and tolerances.

Printer:

Own design

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 to 0.25mm layer height

Infill:

10 to 25% infill

Notes:

author: gal050

print_settings.Printer:: Cherry Pi IIIs with Duet v0.8.5

description.text:
This housing is designed to hold a Pi Zero and camera board in a vertical format suitable for wall, stand or 2020 extrusion mounting. It slides together and doesn't require any screws. The SD card is not accessible from the outside to protected it.

Two designs are included: short and deep (Vert) or tall and thin (Tall). The vert clamp piece applies to both formats.

The cases feature a GoPro compatible mount and I've included a suitable stand, mounting bracket and extension. These need an M5x20 bolt/cap screw and nut although an M5x15 will do it you have them available.

Everything is printable without support. The top piece is designed to print upside down and may benefit from a small amount depending on how your printer/filament copes with overhangs.

Update 09/08/16
At the request of stephenway, I've added a modified Vert Base (PiZeroCamCaseVertBaseLights.STL) with holes and mounting for the "Bright White and IR Camera Light for Raspberry Pi" available from various locations including http://www.robotshop.com/en/bright-white-ir-camera-light-raspberry-pi.html. I haven't printed this case as I don't have the board, but the dimensions where taken from the PCB board definition file so should be close. You will probably have to solder the wires directly to the Pi Zero as I don't think there is space to fit header pins and sockets.

Printer:

Cherry Pi IIIs with Duet v0.8.5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm first later then 0.2mm

Infill:

20%

title: Wire spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spool for wires. With this part you can conveniantly store and transport wires. For example it will hold an isolated wire with a total diameter of 2,5 mm and a length of up to 40 m. If used for thinner wire it will hold much longer wires and you probably will not need the clamp-on parts (just print the "wire_spool_body.stl" file). The clamp-ons fit nicely on the ends and are used to increase the bending radius for thicker wires.

On both sides of the body are clamps for the wires. They not necessarily accommodate all sizes of wires but on the other hand you don't have to use them anyway.

The parts are fairly easy to print, but as the body of the spool has a total length of 196 mm your printer has to support this dimension.

BQ Hephestos
